H0.text: The block with the greatest density is the metal block that raised the temperature of the 10 °C water the most, as determined in the demonstration where four 100‑g blocks of different metals were heated to 60 °C and each was placed in a cup containing 150 g of 10 °C water, with the temperature change measured after 100 s.

H1.text: The block with the lowest surface area raised the temperature of the 10 °C water the greatest amount after 100 s in the demonstration where each of four 100 g metal blocks was heated to 60 °C and placed into separate cups containing 150 g of 10 °C water.

H2.text: The block with the greatest specific heat raised the temperature of the 10 °C water the most after 100 s when four 100‑g metal blocks, each of a different metal, were heated to 60 °C and placed in separate cups containing 150 g of water at 10 °C.

H3.text: The block with the lowest thermal conductivity is the one that raised the temperature of the 10 °C water the greatest amount in the demonstration where four 100 g metal blocks, each of a different metal, were heated to 60 °C and then placed in four cups of 150 g polystyrene foam containing 150 g of 10 °C water, with the temperature change measured after 100 s.

A4.text: good electrical conductors are often also good heat conductors

A5.text: thermal conductivity is a measure of a material's ability to conduct heat; materials with high thermal conductivity transfer heat more efficiently than those with low thermal conductivity
